title: 107_s1073
content: The "National Commission to Eliminate Waste in Government Act of 2001" establishes the National Commission to Eliminate Waste in Government, referred to as the "Commission," with duties outlined. The National Commission to Eliminate Waste in Government is tasked with conducting surveys on management and cost control in the Federal Government, reviewing agency operations, and submitting reports to the President and Congress on significant waste reduction recommendations. The National Commission to Eliminate Waste in Government is responsible for identifying opportunities for increased efficiency and reduced costs in the Federal Government through Executive action or legislation. They also focus on enhancing managerial accountability and administrative control in specific areas of the government. Recommendations for improving the budget process, management, and reducing waste and costs are submitted to the President and Congress. The National Commission to Eliminate Waste in Government aims to enhance accountability and administrative control in specific areas of the Federal Government. Recommendations include terminating programs that have achieved their objectives, outsourcing services to the private sector for cost savings, reforming the budget process for increased efficiency and public confidence, and identifying areas for further study to justify potential savings. SEC. 4. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission shall consist of 12 members, not government officials, appointed based on their qualifications. No more than 6 members can be from the same political party. The President appoints 4 members, the Speaker of the House appoints 3, and the minority appoints 1. The Commission consists of 12 members appointed based on qualifications. Appointments include 4 by the President, 3 by the Speaker of the House, and 1 by the minority leader of the House. Additional appointments are made by the majority and minority leaders of the Senate. Members can continue if they become government officials for up to 30 days. Appointments must be made within 30 days of the Act's enactment, and members serve for the life of the Commission. The Commission consists of 12 members appointed based on qualifications by various officials. Each member serves for the life of the Commission, vacancies are filled within 30 days, and members are not compensated with federal funds. A quorum is five members, a Chairperson is elected from among the members, and meetings are held at least once a month. The Commission's Director is appointed by the Chairperson and paid by the Commission. The Director can appoint staff with Commission approval. The Commission has powers outlined in Section 6. The Commission, as outlined in Section 6, has the authority to hold hearings, receive evidence, delegate actions, obtain information from federal agencies, and enter into contracts for supplies or services. Additionally, the Commission is empowered to request reports as per Section 7. The Commission will issue periodic reports to the President and Congress, with a final report due within 24 months of enactment. The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting the final report. It will be funded, staffed, and equipped by the private sector at no cost to the Federal Government.
